EXTC, EXTC General
38.1 EXTC General
� General Information
The aggregate EXTC ?EXhaust system Temperature Control- concerns the component overheating prevention
and catalyst heating.
38.1.1 Components overheating prevention functions
There are 3 measures to reduce the temperature in the exhaust line. With high temperature ?rst ignition re-
tardation shell be inhibited, because it causes high exhaust temperature due to worse combustion ef?ciency
(used for catalyst heating). The 2 nd measure is the enrichment of the air/fuel mixture, what makes the tem-
perature decrease. The 3rd measure is the reduction of the indicated torque. With high catalyst temperature
especially after a time with enriched mixture it is necessary to inhibit fuel cutoff in pull phase. This function
is located in Appl. Inc. and can be modi?ed by project in "Overheating prevention (Appl. Inc.)". In the ?gure
below the overheating prevention interfaces are marked gray.
1.1.1 Minimum ignition limitation
The inhibition of late ignition angles is realized via limitation of the minimum ignition difference to reference
ignition - IGA_DIF_MIN_TEG. In general this value does not limit the ignition itself, but reduces the torque reserve!
For steady state environment this corresponds to an ignition advance. Dynamic torque reduction via ignition
retardation below IGA_MIN_TEG is allowed!
For direct limitation of the ignition the value IGA_DIF_MIN_TEG_BAS has to limit IGA_DIF_MIN. This function has
to be done by the project in "(TQM) Minimum ignition angle".
According speci?cation: "IGA_MIN limitation for exhaust gas temperature protection"
1.1.2 Enrichment of air-fuel mixture
With richer mixture the exhaust temperature can be lowered. For catalyst overheating prevention there is an
I?controller. The number of temperatures which are to be controlled and their location can be speci?ed in Appl.
Inc. and con?guration. It is recommended to use for controlling static catalyst temperatures to realize a better
control response. For turbine overheating prevention -if existent- there is a P-I- -controller. The lambda-interface
is LAMB_OHP and concerns the minimum of LAMB_COP (for catalyst prevention) and LAMB_TUR_OHP (for
turbine prevention).
According speci?cation: "Overheating prevention (Appl. Inc.)"; "Catalyst overheating prevention"; "Turbocharger
overheating prevention"
1.1.3 Torque reduction
The reduction of the indicated torque shell normally not become effective ? depends on catalyst design. The
function can be activated if the Lambda-setpoint is on bottom limit and the temperature is still high.
According speci?cation: "Torque based overheating prevention"; "Torque based turbine overheating preven-
tion"
38.1.2 Catalyst heating functions
With EXTC you can impact on several setpoints to optimize them for quick light off of the catalyst and for
minimum emissions. Catalyst heating can be activated for after start catalyst heating and for catalyst heating
in low load to avoid temperatures below the catalyst working temperature.
The parameters for catalyst heating are:
?TQ_ADD_CH - torque reserve (results in air mass ?ow and ignition)
?LAMB_SP_CH - air-fuel-mixture
?N_SP_IS_CH - idle speed setpoint

EXTC, EXTC General
These setpoints are inputs for other aggregates and are used if catalyst heating is active. Some of them are
inputs in application incidences of other aggregates and can be used in different ways. The catalyst heating
interfaces are marked black.

� General Information
The following describes the general rules for determination of the con?guration data.
2 COP-controller are used. In the module Overheating prevention (Appl. Inc.) for controlling TEMP_CAT_
MDL and for activation TEG_CAT_UP_MDL is used.
3 variants are used in Torque based catalyst heating (ignition angle and torque, ignition angle only and
torque only)
all axis regarding catalyst heating functions are scalable via different NCs

green) and maps:

� General Information
This module activates the catalyst heating in general and makes a distinction between after start and low load
catalyst heating.
With the con?guration byte C_CONF_CH_LOCK there is the possibility to avoid the repeated activation of CH_
AST or CH_L_LOAD when the subfunctions were active before. The bits in the con?guration byte have the
following meaning:
- C_CONF_CH_LOCK bit 0 = 1 - ->avoid repeated CH_AST activation,
- C_CONF_CH_LOCK bit 1 = 1 - ->avoid repeated CH_L_LOAD activation
- C_CONF_CH_LOCK bit 2 = 1 - ->enable the reset of lock bits at every transition "engine run to engine stop"
- C_CONF_CH_LOCK bit 3 = 1 - - >enable the reset of lock bits at transition "engine run to engine stop" in case
of inactive condition LV_CH_AST_ENA.
- C_CONF_CH_LOCK bit 4 = 1 - - >enable the reset of lock bit (LV_CH_LOCK) at transition "ignition key on to
ignition key of

(CH_L_LOAD, 0x2) are checked via the function call fc_CLC_CH_L_CDN.

38.3.2.1.3 Calculation of CH_L_LOAD condition
The activation of low load catalyst heating depends on the catalyst temperature. TEMP_CAT_DIF_CH_L is the
difference between the actual catalyst temperature and a calibratable temperature setpoint which is to be
reached through heating measures. The value is negative if the catalyst has to be heated up. Via a T_AST
threshold it is possible to make after start catalyst heating higher prior.

This module describes the project speci?c coordination of deactivation behaviour of catalyst heating depend-
ing on actual conditions of engine, environment and FARM. If engine will be operated in catalyst heating mode
after start or not, can be seen easily with the ?ag LV_CH_SET_OFF (see ?gure 12 for input values).

Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: ERU2ES, 100MS, ES2ERU

38.4.4.2 Condition to disable catalyst heating
The bit LV_CH_SET_OFF_tmp is irreversibly set to 1 as soon as the conditions to disable catalyst heating are
ful?lled and this path is not longer calculated. The deactivation of catalyst heating depends mainly on en-
gine conditions like TCO_ST, TAM, TIA_ST and T_AST. Further dependencies are fuel quality (FAC_FQ), type of
transmission (calibration via integral of mass air ?ow, MAF_INT_CH), failure of components and transport- and
production mode.

In this case particular importance are the temperatures of coolant temperature and ambient temperature.
Furthermore failure of components, FARM interface, MAF integral and fuel quality.

38.4.4.3 Calculation of T_AST - correction for catalyst heating
Catalyst heating can also be decreased or deactivated depending on torque and engine speed via IP_TQI_REQ_
TRA_THD_CH, mainly used to allow reduce torque reserve at high and full load demand by driver. To avoid an
undesired deactivation of catalyst heating during highly dynamic conditions during engine start, LV_ST_END
has to be 1 to activate this function.
The bits in the con?guration byte have the following meaning:
C_CONF_CDN_CAT_HEAT bit 0 = 1 - - >means catalyst heating is generally allowed. C_CONF_CDN_CAT_HEAT
bit 1 = 1 - - >means catalyst heating is manually allowed, independent of any conditions. This is used mainly
for application issues and catalyst heating with secondary air (SAWUP). - C_CONF_CDN_CAT_HEAT bit 2 = 1 - ->
means low load catalyst heating is active. C_CONF_CDN_CAT_HEAT bit 3 = 1 - - >means reset of LV_CH_SET_
OFF during engine run to engine stop and LV_IGK = 0 (enable of catalyst heating if catalyst heating is already
?nished).

� General Information
The calculations are very strong dependent of the combustion mode manager. The input variable IDX_CMB_
MOD_CH shows the currently active combustion mode.
The NC_IDX_SUM_CH_SNG checks the actual combustion mode
The NCs for requester are necessary to send the corresponding action to combustion mode manager.

38.5.2.1 Actual Mode
The actual mode is checked via the input variable IDX_CMB_MOD_CH and the corresponding value of NC_IDX_
SUM_CH_SNG. STATE_CH_MODE is used to trigger special MPLH functions for catalyst heating ? for example
extra torque reserve.

38.5.2.2 Requested mode
If STATE_CH is equal to CH_AST, further calculations are carried out to determine the conditions for multiple
injection to be true and than the requests are activated through ACTION_CBMD_SetReq or deactivated through
ACTION_CBMD_ClrReq.
If STATE_CH is currently CH_OFF as compared to not being CH_OFF previously, than the requests for pulsed
injection is all cleared using ACTION_CBMD_ClrReq.

38.5.2.2.1 Calculation under requested mode
The number of pulses could be limited by the bad fuel quality. This guaranted by the map ID_IDX_FQ_INH_
MPLH_CH_CDN. That means only one pulse could be sent to the combustion mode manager with corre-
sponding injection mode e.g. CH_MPI_1. The inhibition of multiple injection all values have to be set to 1.
The table below describes the number of pulses at different injection mode

The requested number of pulses is delivered by the map ID_NR_IV_PLS_REQ_CH and is depending on the input
variable LV_SAWUP which is switching between normal mode and secondary mode. The limitation of pulses
is depending on the NC_NR_MAX_PLS_CH which is delivered from combustion mode manager.
With the map ID_IDX_MOD_REQ_INJ_CH is it possible to choose the injection mode MPI, HPDI and MPI_SA,
HPDI_SA and is also depending on the input variable LV_SAWUP which is switching between normal mode
and secondary air mode.
Be aware at calibration of ID_IDX_MOD_REQ_INJ_CH and ID_NR_IV_PLS_REQ_CH
because they are interdependent (see example below for normal mode).
Map ID_NR_IV_PLS_REQ_CH (number of pulses)
1 1 1 2 2 2 2 2
Map ID_IDX_MOD_REQ_INJ_CH (injection mode)
MPI MPI MPI HPDI HPDI HPDI HPDI HPDI
The variables NR_IV_PLS_REQ_CH and IDX_MOD_REQ_INJ_CH have two conditions. The one condition is to
send the corresponding action to the combustion mode manger. The other condition is to avoid permanent
sending of actions to the combustion mode manager. This means that the old value is different to the new
value then should be send a new request.

� General Information
The minimum ignition angle IGA_DIF_MIN is the minimum allowable retard on ignition angle that is possible to
apply to the engine. Hence, it only includes the combustion stability concern. It does not take into account any
thermal effect. It should be used during the torque intervention phases in order to produce a fast reduction of
the torque.
Applying this minimum ignition angle as actual ignition angle results in ef?ciency losses that leads to an ex-
haust gas overheating and/or engine damages.
In order to avoid overheating of the components in the exhaust-system branch, minimum spark retard has to
be limited in accordance with the actual exhaust gas temperature TEG_DYN_UP_CAT[NC_CYL_CBK_NR].
Moreover to determine the maximum possible torque reserve for catalyst heating, the torque reserve co-
ordination module needs the minimum ignition angle ef?ciency and the minimum ignition angle with exhaust
branch protection ef?ciency in order to limit and choose the different torque reserve requests.
Hence another minimum spark retard difference have to be calculated IGA_DIF_MIN_TEG which takes into
account the exhaust gas system protection. It is the maximum between the one calculated versus the maximal
exhaust gases temperature of TEG_DYN_UP_CAT[NC_CYL_CBK_NR] and the basic one IGA_DIF_MIN.
Classically IGA_DIF_MIN is calculated from a basic value of the minimum ignition angle corrected with a tem-
perature dependent additive term. The basic minimum spark advance is here extracted from a calibration
map.
To calculate the minimum spark retard limitation according to the exhaust gas temperature the map IP_IGA_
DIF_MIN_TEG is used. TEG_HYS_IGA_DIF_MIN is used as input for this map. This intermediate variable TEG_
HYS_IGA_DIF_MINrepresents the exhaust gas temperature TEG_DYN_UP_CAT[NC_CYL_CBK_NR] increased by
an hysterisis in order to anticipate the exhaust-system branch overheat.
So, in all practical cases IGA_DIF_MIN is a negative value that is the maximum allowable spark retard for engine
stable running and pollutant conditions. It includes the coolant temperature correction. The exhaust gas
temperature limitation is then taken into account in IGA_DIF_MIN_TEG.

So, in all practical cases IGA_DIF_MIN is a negative value that is the maximum allowable spark retard for engine
stable running and pollutant conditions. It includes the coolant temperature correction. The exhaust gas
temperature limitation is then taken into account in IGA_DIF_MIN_TEG.
The in?uence of the ignition angle on the exhaust gas temperature results from the ignition angle ef?ciency.
Thus - in order to calibrate easily the map IP_IGA_DIF_MIN_TEG - one should use the ef?ciencies resulting from
IGA_DIF_MIN values with the map IP_EFF_IGA and limit these ef?ciencies according to the actual exhaust gas
temperature to avoid exhaust-system branch overheat.
The actual exhaust gas temperature TEG_DYN_UP_CAT[NC_CYL_CBK_NR] can be either measured by a sensor
on the exhaust-system branch or calculated from an exhaust gas temperature model.
For engines with multiple cylinder banks, this temperature TEG_DYN_UP_CAT of exhaust gas before catalyst
is de?ned and dedicated for each cylinder banks individually. Since here the limitation of ignition retard is
just a protective function versus the catalyst overheating, only the maximal value from all those cylinder bank
related TEG_DYN_UP_CAT temperature will be taken into account.

Note:
Two different update rates are used in the following calculations: for everything related to exhaust temperature
only 100ms rate is used to update calculation in synchronisation with the exhaust temperature updates (the
one of TEG_DYN_UP_CAT[NC_CYL_CBK_NR] or / andTEMP_CAT_DYN_MDL[NC_CYL_CBK_NR]); for calculations
related to ignition angle a 10 time faster update rate of 10ms.
These calculations are only performed when engine is running (not stalled) in homogenous mode after the
end of start phase.

THD_LAMB_CH.

38.7.2.5 Lambda enrichment for automatically decontamination of catalyst.
This function is only calculated when LV_LAMB_SO2P_AUT_ENA is set to 1, NC_CONC_SO2P_AUT_CDN_EXTC is
set to 1 and the bit LC_LAMB_SO2P_AUT_ENA is set to 1.
The LV_LAMB_SO2P_AUT_ENA and LC_LAMB_SO2P_AUT_ENA are coming from torque based catalyst heat-
ing.
The compiler switch NC_CONC_SO2P_AUT_CDN_EXTC is necessary to save resources because all projects do
not use automatically decontamination of catalyst.

EXTC, Catalyst heating correction (Appl. Inc.)
In this module a shift of lambda setpoint during catalyst heating can be calibrated depending on fuel quality.
Fuel quality is determined by start adaption (FAC_FQ_ST_AD), engine roughness based adaption (FAC_FQ) and
lambda based adaptiation (FAC_LAM_AD_WUP).

� General Information
This module is used for catalyst overheating prevention (lambda based) and mentioned also alternative fuel.
In order to protect the catalyst a pre-controlled value is determined (LAMB_COP_PCTL.).

EXTC, Lambda based catalyst overheating prevention
The activation temperature for I-Controller is depending on TEMP_COP_ACT and C_TEMP_COP_ACT_THD.
The controller temperature is depending on TEMP_COP_CTL and C_TEMP_COP_CTL_SP.
The I-Controller can either ramp down the lambda and, is the temperature under the activation threshold,
ramp up. The limitation for lambda is LAMB_COP_MIN and LAMB_COP_PAS.

38.9.2.1 Generation of LAMB_COP_MIN and LAMB_COP_PCTL
LAMB_COP_MIN is the minimum lambda-value for overheating prevention. LAMB_COP_PCTL is a pre-controlled
value and is used for 1st value at controller activation or as additive part during active controller. This is se-
lectable via LC_LAMB_PCTL_INI_COP.
If Alternative Fuel function is requested the LAMB_COP_PCTL and LAMB_COP_MIN- values can be calibrate
separately.

FOR-LOOP for cylinder bank
38.9.2.1.3.1 For Loop - Exhaust Bank selection
38.9.2.1.3.1.1 For Loop - NC_NR_COP_CTL - selection
FOR-LOOP COP-Controller =>t -selection
38.9.2.1.3.1.1.1 Activation/Deactivation
This function is inside a nested for-loop-system - one loop from 1 to NC_CBK_EX_NR (index = i) and the other
one from 1 to NC_NR_COP_CTL (index = t).
NC_NR_COP_CTL is the number of catalyst overheating prevention controllers. TEMP_COP_CTL and TEMP_
COP_ACT can contain 1 or 2 bankselective (NC_CBK_EX_NR) temperatures for e.g. exhaust gas temperature
before catalyst and temperature in the catalyst.
The activation of the lambda controllers (for each bank 1 or 2 controllers) is done via TEMP_COP_ACT and
C_TEMP_COP_ACT_THD.
If LAMB_OHP >LAMB_BAS_i the lambda value is ramped up again and the controller can be deactivated.

38.9.2.1.3.1.1.1.3 Bus system I-controller
38.9.2.1.3.1.1.1.3.1 Integrator-Controller - Subsystem
This I controller is developed to be used with static temperatures, because in this way the control path is
eliminated to avoid undesirable oscillation.
C_TEMP_COP_CTL_SP_t minus TEMP_COP_CTL _i_t is the control deviation.
The block "IntegratorKREL" integrates the Product of C_FAC_LAMB_COP_INC/DEC_t and the control deviation.
C_FAC_LAMB_COP_DEC is used at too high temperature for ramping lambda down and C_FAC_LAMB_COP_INC
vice versa. The output is limited to LAMB_COP_MIN and LAMB_COP_PAS.
If LC_ LAMB_PCTL_INI_COP is 1 the controller works as I-controller. If the LC is 0, the pre-controlled part via
IP_LAMB_COP_PCTL is also used.

� General Information
If a turbo charger variant exists the actual temperature before turbine TEG_DYN_UP_TUR exceeds TEG_TUR_
OHP_SP (calibratable via IP_TEG_TUR_UP_SP) the logical value LV_LAMB_TUR_OHP is set to 1 and a P-I-controller
is activated. LAMB_TUR_OHP is ramped down to decrease the turbine temperature and afterwards (at uncriti-
cal temperatures) ramped up until LAMB_BAS to avoid a step in LAMB_SP.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: LV_ST_END==1&&LV_TCHA_CONF==1
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: 10MS

38.10.2.1.1.1 Calculation of TEG_TUR_OHP_SP
The target temperature for the controller is generated via IP_TEG_TUR_UP_SP and IP_TEG_TUR_UP_OFS_SP . If
this value is increasing it is ?ltered via C_CRLC_TEG_TUR_OHP_SP.
The map IP_TCO_COR_TEG_TUR_UP_SP is used to weighting of output of IP_TEG_TUR_UP_OFS_SP with IP_TCO_
COR_TEG_TUR_UP_SP.
The timer is only activated if TCO within the limitations C_TCO_TEG_TUR_SP_LIM_MAX and C_TCO_TEG_TUR_
SP_LIM_MIN.
RVC_SP means the setpoint of rotary valve coolant position =>control of different water-cooling-ways

EXTC, Lambda based turbine overheating prevention
38.10.2.1.1.2.2 Controller - subsystem
For loop system
The calculations in this subsystem and lower are done for each exhaust bank separately the variables have
the index n. TEG_TUR_OHP_DIF is the control deviation and input for the controller. If it has negative values the
temperature is too high and the controller is activated. There are two parts of the controller: 1. RAMP_DOWN for
too high temperature and 2. RAMP_UP for deactivation ramp if TEG_TUR_OHP_DIF is again in positive range.
LAMB_OHP <= LAMB_BAS is used for deactivation - to ramp LAMB_TUR_OHP until LAMB_BAS.

38.10.2.1.1.2.2.1 Bus system RAMP UP
38.10.2.1.1.2.2.1.1 RAMP UP Subsystem
Ramping lambda up
If the temperature is lower than the setpoint the lambda-setpoint is ramped up again via P-Part and I-Part. With
LC_LAMB_TUR_OHP_RAMP_UP it is ensured that the I-Part independent from the control deviation increases.
The I-part is frozen as long as the torque reduction for overheating prevention is active (LV_TQI_TEG_MAX_
TUR=1).

38.10.2.1.1.2.2.2 Bus system RAMP DOWN
38.10.2.1.1.2.2.2.1 Ramp down -subsystem
Ramping lambda down
If temperature is in critical range the lambda-setpoint is ramped down via a P-Part and an I-Part to reduce the
temperature. Via LC_LAMB_TUR_OHP_RAMP_DOWN it can be ensured that the I-part is ramped down inde-
pendent from the control deviation (with too small control deviation LAMB_TUR_OHP_I keeps its old value).

38.10.2.1.1.2.2.3 Bus system active controller
38.10.2.1.1.2.2.3.1 Controller active
OHP-controller active -limitation of controller outputs
During active controller, the I- and P-Part either from RAMP_UP or from RAMP_DOWN subsystem are added.
The I-Part and the addition-result are minimum-imitated. If one of this limitations is reached LV_LAMB_TUR_
OHP_BOL is set to 1.
The limitation of LV_LAMB_TUR_OHP_BOL is depending on PI-part. This is necessary for the delay to ramp up
LAMB_TUR_OHP.

� General Information
TEMP_COP_ACT (activation temperature) and TEMP_COP_CTL (controller temperature) are used in the mod-
ule "Catalyst overheating prevention". The exhaust gas temperature before catalysator and the catalysator
temperature are controlled for each bank therefore the outputs are matrices (x-dimension: NC_CBK_EX_NR;
y-dimension NC_NR_COP_CTL).
The driving-up hill functionality has also impact to the above temperatures if the switch LC_DRI_OHP_CAT_UP_
ENA is set to 1.
The function enrichment via gear shift decide to freeze the above temperatures during gear shift.

38.11.2 Formula section
38.11.2.1 100 ms Task
LV_PUC_INH_TEMP_CAT is set depending on catalyst temperature thresholds and reset after passing a hys-
teresis or if the clutch is opened or the driver request is 0. The activation threshold depends on a special
MAF-integral that increases during mixture enrichment (HC-storage) and decreases in stoichiometric or even
lean mixture.
With C_CALC_TEMP_CAT_GRD you can calibrate how often the gradient-calculation is triggered. The factor
C_CALC_TEMP_CAT_GRD is multiplied with the "function-sample-time" of 100 ms. Example: if C_CALC_TEMP_
CAT_GRD = 2, the gradient is calculated each 200 ms.
The temperature gradient TEG_TUR_OHP_GRD is input for the activation function of torque limitation due to
overtemperature.

38.11.2.1.1 For system
38.11.2.1.1.1 Nested For-system
There are 2 temperature-controller for catalyst overheating prevention. The 1st one controls the temperatures
before the catalyst and the 2nd one the catalyst temperature itself. For activation dynamic temperatures are
used (TEG_DYN_UP_CAT and TEMP_CAT_DYN_MDL) and for controlling static temperatures are used (TEG_
STAT_UP_CAT and TEMP_CAT_STAT_MDL).
Further it is possible to interpolate between the stationary and the dynamic catalyst temperature as input
to the controller deviation calculation. So the stationary temperature (FAC_TEMP_COP_CTL_DYN_STAT = 0)
should be used at HIGH/USUAL dynamic. The dynamic temperature should be used at LOW dynamic
(quasi-stationary operation conditions) to avoid needles rich lambda because of the smooth heating up of the
tubes and catalyst.
The temperature gradient is not used until 1,1s after start. That?s done because TEMP_CAT_DYN_MDL is ini-
tialised in-between this time and high, unreal gradients can occur.
With C_CALC_TEMP_CAT_GRD you can calibrate how often the gradient-calculation is triggered. The factor
C_CALC_TEMP_CAT_GRD is multiplied with the "function-sample-time" of 100 ms. Example: if C_CALC_TEMP_
CAT_GRD = 2, the gradient is calculated each 200 ms.
The temperature gradient TEG_TUR_OHP_GRD is input for the activation function of torque limitation due to
overtemperature.

38.11.2.1.2 Subsystem - Calculation hill functionality
38.11.2.1.2.1 Calculation of enable hill functionality
The driving up-hill functionality is controlled via LC_DRI_OHP_CAT_UP_ENA. The calculation is enabled if LC_
DRI_OHP_CAT_UP_ENA = 1.
The calculations are very strong dependent of the combustion mode manager. The input variable IDX_CMB_
MOD_CUR shows the currently active combustion mode.
The following NCs are necessary to check the actual combustion mode
NC_IDX_CH_1
NC_IDX_CH_2
NC_IDX_CH_2_S_1
NC_IDX_CH_3_S_2
NC_IDX_CH_MPI_1
NC_IDX_CH_MPI_2_S
NC_IDX_CH_SA_2_S_1
NC_IDX_CH_SA_3_S_1
NC_IDX_CH_SA_MPI_2
NC_IDX_CH_SA_MPI_2_S_1
NC_IDX_CH_SA_MPI_3_S_1
The map ID_IDX_CMB_MOD_CUR_CH is calibratable with 0 and 1. This means driving up-hill is active (1) or not
(0) depending on actually combustion mode.The axis of ID_IDX_CMB_MOD_CUR_CH is not tunable.

38.11.2.1.2.1.1 Calculation of driving up-hill
The variable TEMP_COP_ACT is the threshold for activation and deactivation for COP controller. During driv-
ing up-hill the real temperature (TEMP_COP_ACT) can be replaced/overwriten by a corrected temperature
(COR_COP_ACT) in order to prevent overheating. To prevent a high fuel-consumption because of Lambda-
enrichment during overheating prevention the corrected temperature is only used if the Temperature-limit
(C_TEMP_CAT_OHP_LIM) is exeeded for a certain time (C_T_ST_COP_ACT_ENA). Additionaly (if once activated)
the corrected temperature can be held for a certain time (C_T_ST_COP_OFS_ENA) if the Temperature falls
below the activation-limit. Deatailed behaviour is shown in Chapter 1.2.1.2.1.1.1 Calculation of timer.

38.11.2.1.2.1.1.1 Calculation of timer
This module is only necessary for driving up-hill. In this module the different timers, which manage the usage
of uncorrected (TEMP_COP_ACT_TMP) or corrected (TEMP_COP_ACT_TMP + ID_TEG_COR_COP_ACT = COR_
COP_ACT) Temperature, are calculated.
The initialisation of general timer is generated via LV_T_ST_COP_ACT_ENA and the timer counts down to
zero.
The initialisation of offset timer is generated via LV_T_ST_COP_ACT_OFS_ENA and the timer counts down to
zero.
If the general timer has reached zero the corrected/higher temperature COR_COP_ACT is used, otherwise
TEMP_COP_ACT is used.
The timer counts down with the recurrence of module.
File: 15707U02.00P
11080Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

EXTC, Overheating prevention (Appl. Inc.)
If the offset timer has reached zero the corrected/higher temperature COR_COP_ACT is replaced by the real
Temperature again.
The timer counts downs with the recurrence of module.
The re-initialisation of both timers is only possible when COR_COP_ACT_MAX is below the limitation and both
timers are zero.

38.11.3 Calculation of LAMB_OHP_EXT
This function should only activated if gear shift of selected variant is done without cylinder shut off.
LAMB_OHP_EXT is used for precontrolled fast enrichment due to late ignition angle. If catalyst heating is
deactivated and the TRANS_TYP (gearbox code) depending on ID_LAMB_OHP_GS_CONF is set, the function is
calculated otherwise the output is set to 32. That is the passive value that has no effect on LAMB_SP.

38.11.3.1.1 Calculation of activation conditions for enrichment due to gear shift
This function works for cars with all transmissions. If a predicted gear shift is recognized and the catalyst
temperature exceeds a calibrateable threshold, the function is triggered. Depending on the shift direction (up
or down), values out of IP_LAMB_OHP_GS_UP/DOWN will be calculated.
The deactivation of enrichment via gear-shift occurs only at following condition:
- cylinder shut off
- high temperature of lambda sensor upstream
- high temperature of catalyst
This function describes the amount of torque at gear-shift-changes which has to be decreased. If gear-shift
occurs and the depleted torque intervention is slow the enrichment is not triggered (LV_CDN_LAMB_OHP_
GS).
If you drive with high dynamic and the depleted torque intervention at gear-shift is high the enrichment will
be triggered (LV_CDNLAMB_OHP_GS).

EXTC, Overheating prevention (Appl. Inc.)
The activation of enrichment will be calculated only if there is no cylinder shut off (INH_SWI_IV = 0) and if either
TEG_DYN_LS_UP (temperature lambda sensor upstream) or TEMP_CAT_DYN_MDL_OHP (catalyst temperature)
exceed a certain threshold (IP_TEMP_CAT_MIN_THD_LAMB_OHP_GS).
Hint to ID_T_DLY_LAMB_OHP_GS_SET
If a gear-shift is recognized, the Reset-value of Timer-Trigger-RE-Block is written with ID_T_DLY_LAMB_OHP_GS_
SET. If the gear now will not changed any more, the counter is count down to zero (normal Reset) with the
value of ID_T_DLY_LAMB_OHP_GS_SET.
During the timer (SET) is running to zero, the output-value of Timer-Trigger-RE-Block is "1". Therefore LV_CDN_
LAMB_OHP_GS is set to "1".
Hint to ID_T_DLY_CDN_LAMB_OHP_GS:
IF the gearbox-controller unit recognizes that the gear-shift is done (the torque is not any more reduced) the
difference of old torque TQI_GS_DYN_TCUE_OLD) request to actual torque request (TQI_GS_DYN_TCUE) which
is smaller than a certain threshold C_TQI_OHP_GS_DYN_THD is set a ?ip?op to reset the enrichment (LV_CDN_
LAMB_OHP_GS = 0) after a certain delay which is de?ned from ID_T_DLY_CDN_LAMB_OHP_GS.
Hint to ID_T_DLY_LAMB_OHP_GS_RST:
The Reset-delay with ID_T_DLY_LAMB_OHP_GS_RST is initialized during counting down of SET-Timer.
If the SET-Timer is elapsed, the Reset-timer is running down to zero and the LV_CDN_LAMB_OHP_GS (lambda-
enrichment) is disabled.

38.11.3.1.1.1 Calculation enable of enrichment via torque
The activation of enrichment for rich lambda within gear shift is depending on torque decrement for fast
torque intervention.
With the LC_TQI_GS_STGY_ENA = 1 the rich-lambda-function depending on difference between TQI_BAS and
TQI_GS_FAST_DEC.
With the LC_TQI_GS_STGY_ENA = 0 the rich-lambda function is calculated without the torque impact.

38.11.3.2 Freeze catalyst temperature for COP-controller
The enrichment via gear has impact to the COP-controller. During the COP-controller is active and you en-
gaged the gear the ignition angle will be retard in order to reduce the torque reserve. During change of
gear the lambda will be decrease for short time. This has also impact to the static temperature and the COP-
controller see a high temperature and react to fat.
The temperatures TEMP_COP_ACT and TEMP_COP_CTL must be freeze during engaged the gear.

� General Information
This module determines catalyst overheating prevention at high valve lift overlapping. Therefore it is necessary
to protect the catalyst. The background is scavenging. In this case the cylinder has higher air mass which
causes very high temperature in catalyst.
Scavenging is also active with the operating temperature; the calculation should take place only from a certain
threshold. If this threshold (C_TEMP_CAT_MIN_SCAV_THD_CH) is crossed, the present catalyst temperature
is compared ?rst to the preceding one. This delta (TEMP_CAT_SCAV_DELTA ) is added up on the current
temperature of the catalyst (TEMP_CAT_SCAV_DELTA_REAC_MAX_CH) in order to check whether scavenging
should be already deactivated in this recurrence.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: always

38.13.2.1.1 Calculation of FAC_SUF_MASS_HEAT_CH
The maps IP_DIST_MASS_HEAT_COR_FAC_CH, IP_DIST_COR_FAC_CH and IP_FAC_EFF_CAT_DIAG_CH calculates
the factor for FAC_SUF_MASS_HEAT_CH. if LC_FAC_SUF_MASS_HEAT_CH set to 1 and no failure is occurred.
Via C_FAC_SUF_MASS_HEAT_MASS_CH is it possible to use an calibratable value independent of pre-calculation.
The suf?cient catalyst haeting module is also mentioned FARM and limp home. In this case a certain factor
C_FAC_SUF_MASS_HEAT_CH_MIS is used.

measures. In combination with the ignition spark retardation and the lambda setpoint the warm-up of the
catalyst can be guaranteed.

38.14.3.1 Calculation of N_SP_IS_CH
There are several maps mainly for automatric transmission) for engaged gear and not engaged in order to
calculate the correct idle speed setpoint. If no automatic transmission available the manual transmission is
valid.
The maps for automatric transmission are depending on STATE_TRANS_TYP which are choose the correct
map for different kind of gearboxes. The number of arrays is affected by NC_NR_TRANS_TYP.
Offset map (IP_N_SP_IS_CH_OFS:
The duration of catalyst heating is controlled via adaptive catalyst heating (FAC_SUF_MASS_HEAT_CH). In some
cases the temperature for catalyst heating could not be achieved in exhaust gas test for old catalysts. The
reducing of NOx-emissions during the warm-up phase is possible.

� General Information
Using the factor FAC_COR_N_WUP_GB the automatic gearbox has the possibility to correct his gear shift pro-
gram. The value 0...100 % represents a scaling factor between a fuel consumption optimized gear shift program
(0 %) and a exhaust gas emission optimized gear shift program (100 %).

38.15.2 Bus system to calculate FAC_COR_N_WUP_GB
38.15.2.1 Overview
In case of active calculation the transmitted value (FAC_COR_N_WUP_GB is CAN output) is mainly depending
on catalyst heating state and gearbox type. The value can be adjusted depending on engine start temperature
and time after start. A correction depending on catalyst ef?ciency and time after start is considered.

EXTC, Torque based catalyst heating
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
Basic torque reserve for after start catalyst heating with multiple injection
LC_IGA_ENA_TQ_ADD_CH - 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Logical constant for catalyst heating by ignition angle preset
LC_LAMB_SO2P_AUT_ENA - 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Manual switch to enable the automatically decontamination of catalyst
� Action De?nitions
ACTION_EXTC_ClearSo2pSrv() Mode: O
Disable decontamination of catalyst via tester
ACTION_EXTC_SetSo2pSrv() Mode: O
Enable decontamination of catalyst
ACTION_EXTC_SetSo2pSrvStatus(OUT <PRM_SO2P_SRV_STATUS>) Mode: O
Status decontamination of catalyst
Parameter Type Hex.Limits Phys.Limits Resol. Unit
PRM_SO2P_SRV_STATUS OUT 0... FFH 0... 255 1 -
The status contamination of catalyst is either active (0xC0) or inactive (0x10)
� General Information
This module determinates catalyst heating via torque reserve. You can choose two ways either ignition angle
or normal torque.
Also decontamination of catalyst via tester has impact of torque reserve.

Figure 38.16.14:
38.16.2.2.1 Torque correction for transmission variants with MPLH_CH
Project which use ignition angle to calculate torque reserve LC_IGA_ENA_TQ_ADD_CH must be set to one.
To ful?ll the emission standards and to improve driveability it is useful to have different calibration maps for
torque reserve. Depending on the transmission variant TQ_ADD_CH can be calibrated separat for AT / DCT
/ CVT / MT. Additional it is possible to distinguish between idle speed and part load. Further more for AT and
DCT and CVT variantes separate maps for drive train engaged or disengaged can be calibtared (LV_DRI = 0 or
LV_DRI = 1)
Alternatively it is possible to adjust a preset value for the ignition angle (LC_IGA_ENA_TQ_ADD_CH = 1).This de-
sired IGA setpoint is then transformed to the according torque correction.

Figure 38.16.15:
38.16.2.2.1.1 Calculation of ignition angle preset for CH (IGA-MPLH)
The ignition angle is depends on different kind of transmissions during multiple injection. The calculation
mentions automatic transmission (LV_AT = 1), manual transmission (LV_AT = 0), drive position is engaged (LV_
DRI = 1. ) and idle speed (LV_IS = 1).
The STATE_GB_TYP_AT will given automatically the current automatic transmission and show instead the value
the correct name (e.g. MT for manual transmission).
In order to adjustment / correction IGA_CH_SP via condition of temperatures and duration of catalyst heating
is it possible to move the absolute ignition angle (IGA_ADD_CH_SP). The basic map IP_IGA_ADD_MPLH_CH_SP
will be multiplied with the correction factor. This factor symbolize the duration of catalyst heating (T_AST or
the relative MAF-integral) and deactivate the impact of offset (FAC=0) or the applicable movement of ignition
angle (FAC=1). The investigation of the factors is the consideration of the maximum from the both factor-maps
in order to cover different states of driving conditions (time behavior of catalyst heating).

AUT_ACT and the continuous integral MAF_INT_CH_SO2P_AUT_NVMY will be set to zero

38.16.3 Enable calculation of ?nal torque reserve
This function block is necessary for calculation of ignition angle in certain calculation with TQDR. EXTC calcu-
lates the ignition angle IGA_DIF_CH_BAS and delivered to TQDR. The feedback is the ef?ciency ignition angle
to calculates exactly the torque reserve.
Therefore the calculation order is as following: EXTC (IGA_DIF_CH_BAS) = >TQDR(...) = >EXTC (TQ_ADD_CH)
and all must be done in the same recurrence.

Figure 38.16.42:
38.16.4.1.1 Display status of decontamination of catalyst
The parameter PRM_SO2P_SRV_STATUS will be set to display the status inactive or active decontamination
of catalyst. This status is depending on the LV_SO2P_SRV which is responsible to activate the function for
decontamination. The value 192 (0xC0) means the function decontamination is running. The value 16 (0x10)
means the function decontamination is not running.

38.17.2.2.1 SUBSYSTEM for Calculation from EFF_IGA_CST_LIM
The external factor EFF_IGA_CST_LIM_EXT_ADJ, delivered by the serial communication interface, de?nes the
upper limit for an ef?ciency output during the catalyst heating phase. This ef?ciency limit is transformed into a
minimum torque reserve TQ_ADD_MIN_CH again and then considered in the calculation of the overall reserve
for catalyst heating (condition of CSERS).

� General Information
The torque based turbine overheating prevention is an additional way after lthe lambda enrichment to reduce
the turbine temperature. Therefore the information for lambda turbo overheating prevention will be used for
the activation and calculation of the TQ-intervention. If the lambda enrichment is not suf?cient to reduce of
exhaust gas temperature on the turbine the calculation of the torque intervention will be activated. Additional
to this torque intervention the overspeed- and wastegate in?uence is considered on the charger side.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: always
Deactivation: never

C_TEG_MIN_POW_COP - 0... 7FFFH -273.15... 1774.788 0.0625 �C
Threshold of exhaust gas temperature for activation of COP power limitation
� General Information
In case of critical catalyst temperatures the exhaust gas is cooled down by enrichment. If the lambda runs
below the threshold C_LAMB_COP_POW_MIN the engine power has to be reduced as a second path to limit
the maximum exhaust gas temperature. Once the exhaust gas temperature falls below C_TEG_POW_LIM the
maximum engine power is ramped up again to the maximum value. These ramps have to calibrated slow to
prevent a bad in?uence of driveability.

38.20 Catalyst heating (gen)
� Calibration interfering functions
- Intake manifold model must be calibrated

? Exhaust gas temperature model must be calibrated

� Calibration method
In the module "Catalyst heating coordination" catalyst heating in general is activated and activates also the
setpoint calculations (Idle speed setpoint for CH, Torque based catalyst heating and Catalyst heating coor-
dination). These setpoints can be calibrated passive: N_SP_IS_CH = 0, LV_N_SP_IS_CH = 0; TQ_ADD_CH = 0;
LAMB_CH = 1; LV_LAMB_CH = 0. So there is a free catalyst heating strategy.
First the catalyst heating calibration for single injection shell be done (left part of calibration ?ow chart). Where
it won?t be possible to keep the module-wise order because the functions impact themselves. Based on this
the multiple injection calibration can be done. Their in?uences on some normal catalyst heating setpoints are
handled in these modules - therefore the 2nd loop in the ?owchart above.

EXTC, Catalyst heating (gen)
Coordination of multiple injection in homogenous mode (MPLH)
The coordination of multiple injection is done in the aggregate CBMD "Combustion Modes". STATE_CH_MOD_
REQ is the request of MPLH for catalyst heating. If it is possible to activate MPLH the bit LV_MPLH_REQ is set to
1 in CBMD. With this bit the air mass ?ow is increased via EFF_TQI_COR_CUS and if it is possible to switch over
under torque neutral conditions, the multiple injection is activated via LV_MPLH_INJ_REQ. After a calibratable
number of segments the ignition is switch to MPLH - parameters. LV_MPLH_ACT is set after actually activation
of MPLH (reaction of BSW). The time ?ow is diagrammed in the next picture.

EXTC, Catalyst heating (gen)
IP_T_AST_THD_CH_AST This map describes the general (maximum) time for 
activation of after start heating. The separate catalyst 
heating measures (sec air, ignition influence, idle 
speed setpoint increase and lambda setpoint for CH) 
cannot be calibrated for a longer time. 
C_TEMP_CAT_THD_CH_AST If the catalyst temperature is above this value, after 
start catalyst heating will be deactivated or not be 
activated - for example after hot start. 
Attention: Sometimes the exhaust gas temperature 
values will be initialized with maximum values. 
C_TEMP_CAT_THD_CH_L_ON The value describes the catalyst temperature 
threshold where catalyst heating for low load heating 
will be activated. 
C_TEMP_CAT_THD_CH_L_OFF The value describes the catalyst temperature 
threshold where catalyst heating for low load heating 
will be deactivated. 
C_T_AST_MIN_CH_L_LOAD For this time the low load catalyst heating is inhibited. 
So it's assured that after start catalyst heating is 
higher prior than low load catalyst heating. 
 
Torque based catalyst heating:
The torque model calculates the spark retardation for catalyst heating depending on the air mass ?ow
increase.
IP_TQ_ADD_CH_AST Basic value for torque reserve calculation for after start 
catalyst heating depending on the engine speed and 
TQI_REQ_TRA. 
IP_TQ_ADD_CH_AST_IS Basic value for torque reserve calculation for after start 
catalyst heating in idle speed depending on the engine speed 
and TQI_REQ_TRA. 
IP_FAC_TQ_ADD_CH_AST Correction of the torque reserve calculation for after start 
catalyst heating depending on TCO_ST and T_AST.  It can be 
used to ramp the torque reserve. 
 
According to these maps there are extra maps for MPLH (multiple injection). The output of these extra
maps is added up to the torque reserve for homogenous, single injection depending on STATE_CH_
MOD.
Maps: IP_TQ_ADD_MPLH_CH_AST, IP_TQ_ADD_ MPLH_CH_AST_IS and IP_FAC_TQ_ADD_ MPLH_CH_

C_TQ_ADD_CH_FIL_LGRD Limitation gradient for TQ_ADD_REQ_ACT_FIL_CH. 
If it is set to 0,TQ_ADD_REQ_ACT_FIL_CH stays 0 and the 
torque reserve can be used for dynamic torque intervention - 
the ignition angle can be advanced. 
If it is set > 0, TQ_ADD_REQ_ACT_FIL_CH rises up to 
TQ_ADD_CH (for steady state environment) and the torque 
model inhibits that this reserve is used for fast increase of 
indicated torque through ignition advance. 
C_TQ_ADD_CH_LGRD Limitation gradient for TQ_ADD_CH during deactivation of 
catalyst heating to avoid large steps of ignition angle. 
IP_TQ_ADD_CH_L Basic map of the torque reserve calculation for low load 
catalyst heating depending on engine speed and 
TQI_REQ_TRA. 
IP_TQ_ADD_CH_L_IS Basic map of the torque reserve calculation for low load 
catalyst heating in idle speed depending on engine speed and 
TQI_REQ_TRA. 
IP_FAC_TQ_ADD_CH_L Correction of the torque reserve calculation for low load 
catalyst heating depending on the difference between the 
actual and the setpoint of catalyst temperature. In principle its 
a precontrolled P-controller. 
 
Catalyst heating correction:
For catalyst heating during the warm-up after start, the engine can be operated with a lean air-fuel ratio
or -if installed- rich secondary air setpoint.
IP_T_AST_THD_LAMB_CH This map describes the (corrected) time after start 
where the lean mixture for CH is active (depending on 
TCO_ST). With STATE_CH ~= 1 LV_LAMB_CH is also 
set to 0. 
IP_LAMB_ADD_CH This map describes the additive correction of the 
lambda setpoint during CH depending on T_AST and 
TCO. 
IP_LAMB_CH_IS This map describes the basic lambda setpoint for lean 
mixture during idle depending on TQI_REQ_SLOW and 
engine speed. 
IP_LAMB_CH_RGL This map describes the basic lambda setpoint for lean 
mixture out of idle depending on TQI_REQ_SLOW and 
engine speed. 
 
According to these maps there are extra maps for MPLH (multiple injection). Between this several maps
will be switch depending on STATE_CH_MOD.
Calibrate the lambda setpoint respect to target engine roughness and lowest emissions. In general the
Lambda setpoint will be stoichiometric or lean to decrease HC. The NOx-emissions are reduced due to
cold engine. Pay attention to the in?uence of fuel quality!
Fuel pressure for catalyst heating
This function provides a special fuel pressure setpoint for catalyst heating. There are several maps for
single and multiple injection. Effects in?uenced by fuel pressure that have to be taken into consideration
are wetting of piston, inlet valve and cylinder wall, fuel atomisation, strati?cation of 2 nd pulse.
IP_FUP_RES_H_SP_MPLH_CH Fuel pressure for catalyst heating with activated multiple 
injection.  
IP_FUP_RES_H_SP_CH  Fuel pressure for catalyst heating with single injection 
C_FUP_RES_H_SP_CH_PAS Passive value for fuel pressure setpoint if catalyst 
heating is deactivated.

� Calibration interfering functions
- Intake manifold model must be calibrated

� Calibration ?owchart
The sequence is also described by the order in Calibrated methods.
Catalyst overheating 
prevention 
Torque based overheating 
prevention 
IGA_MIN_limitation 
� Calibration method
There are 3 ways to protect the components (catalyst and turbine) against overheating:
? Via IGA_DIF_MIN_TEG the torque reserve and so the ignition retardation is limited
? Through LAMB_OHP the air-fuel-ratio can be reduced
? TQI_MAX_OHP limits the indicated torque - passive calibratable
IGA_MIN limitation for exhaust gas temperature protection:
The minimum ignition angle IGA_DIF_MIN is the minimum allowable retard on the ignition angle that is
possible to apply to the engine. Hence, it only includes the combustion stability concern.
In order to avoid overheating of the components in the exhaust gas system branch, minimum spark
retard has to be limited in accordance with the actual exhaust gas temperature.
C_TEG_MAX_IGA The value describes the maximum allowable exhaust 
gas temperature for spark retardation control. 
C_TEG_MAX_IGA_HYS The value describes the hysteresis for the exhaust gas 
temperature for spark retardation control. 
IP_IGA_DIF_MIN_TEG The map contains the minimum ignition angle difference 
depending on the exhaust gas temperature for 
component protection. 
 
Catalyst overheating prevention
The module contains 1. the lambda calculation for catalyst overheating prevention that is done via a
precontrolling and I-controller and 2. the merging with the lambda setpoint for turbine overheating pre-
vention.

This image displays a Simulink-like block diagram, representing a software function for automotive control.

## Function
The primary function of this Simulink diagram, titled "EXTC: Catalyst heating coordination," is to manage and coordinate the heating process of an automotive catalytic converter. It monitors various engine and system conditions, calculates the necessary heating parameters, and controls the operational state of the catalyst heating system to ensure efficient emissions reduction, particularly during cold starts. It incorporates ignition status-dependent logic and operates on a periodic schedule.

## Inputs
The system receives a multitude of inputs, primarily from the `APP_CDN V.7.3` block, and internal system signals:

*   **`<LV_CH_AST_ENA>`**: Catalyst heating assistant enable.
*   **`<T_AST_DG>`**: Temperature for heating assistant diagnosis.
*   **`<TEMP_CAT_DYN_MDL_OHP>`**: Dynamic model temperature for catalyst overheat protection.
*   **`<LV_CH_L_ENA>`**: Catalyst heating lower limit enable.
*   **`<LV_LAMB_OHP>`**: Lambda (air-fuel ratio) overheat protection.
*   **`<LV_TQI_OHP>`**: Torque limitation overheat protection.
*   **`<NC_CBK_EX_NR>`**: Number of exhaust strokes.
*   **`<LV_ES>`**: Engine start status.
*   **`<LV_IGK>`**: Ignition key status (ON/OFF).
*   **`<ACTION_FARM_SetAuxiliaryStatus_T3>`**: Auxiliary status setting action.
*   **`<FAC_SUF_MASS_HEAT_CH>`**: Factor for sufficient mass heating of the catalyst.
*   **`<TCO_ST_DG>`**: Coolant temperature status for diagnosis.
*   **`<NC_NB_FAC_SUF_MASS_HEAT_T_AST>`**: Number of cycles for sufficient mass heating temperature assistant.
*   **`<NC_NR_T_AST_DG_T_AST>`**: Number of cycles for temperature assistant diagnosis.
*   **`init`**: System initialization signal (for INI X.1).
*   **`input`**: General input signal (fed to INI X.1, fc_IGKOFF(), fc_IGKONOFF()).
*   **`feedback`**: A feedback signal (fed to OPM X.2), suggesting a closed-loop control or state machine.

## Outputs
The system produces the following key outputs from the `V.6.4` block:

*   **`<LV_CH>`**: Status or control value for catalyst heating.
*   **`<STATE_CH>`**: The current operational state of the catalyst heating system.
*   **`<TEMP_CAT_DIF_CH_L>`**: Temperature difference related to catalyst heating, possibly a target or measured value for control.

Internal outputs within V.6.4 also provide more granular data:
*   `LV_CH: O V`
*   `LV_CH_LOCK: V`
*   `LV_CH_L_CDN: V`
*   `LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK: V`
*   `NR_CTR_L_LOAD_CH_CYC: V`
*   `STATE_CH: O V`
*   `TEMP_CAT_DIF_CH_L: O V`

## Logic Flow
The function operates with a recurrence of 100ms and is always activated, processing various inputs to coordinate catalyst heating.

1.  **Initialization (INI X.1):** The process begins with the `INI X.1` block, which receives `init` and `input` signals. This block is responsible for setting up the initial state or parameters of the catalyst heating system, potentially based on a system reset (`RST`) or specific ECU events (`ERU2ES`).

2.  **Ignition-Dependent Logic (`fc_IGKOFF()`, `fc_IGKONOFF X.3`):**
    *   The `fc_IGKOFF()` function receives an `input` signal and generates `clc_lv_ch_lock`. This block likely determines the locking state or conditions for catalyst heating when the ignition is switched off, potentially to prevent unintended heating or manage residual heat.
    *   The `fc_IGKONOFF X.3` block also receives an `input` and is associated with ignition status (ON/OFF). Both `fc_IGKOFF` and `fc_IGKONOFF` contribute to the overall control logic related to ignition states.

This block likely determines the locking state or conditions for catalyst heating when the ignition is switched off, potentially to prevent unintended heating or manage residual heat.
    *   The `fc_IGKONOFF X.3` block also receives an `input` and is associated with ignition status (ON/OFF). Both `fc_IGKOFF` and `fc_IGKONOFF` contribute to the overall control logic related to ignition states.

3.  **Periodic Function Call (`fc_10MS()`):**
    *   An `input` signal (potentially `clc_lv_ch_lock` from `fc_IGKOFF()`) feeds into the `fc_10MS()` block. This indicates a function that executes every 10 milliseconds, producing an `opm` signal. This `opm` signal acts as an input to the main operational manager.

4.  **Operational Manager (OPM X.2):**
    *   The `OPM X.2` block is the central processing unit. It gathers the `opm` signal from `fc_10MS()`, a `feedback` signal (indicating a stateful or closed-loop operation), and a large array of environmental, engine, and control inputs from `APP_CDN V.7.3` (e.g., enable flags, temperatures, ignition status, engine start status, overheat protection flags).
    *   Based on these comprehensive inputs, the `OPM` determines the appropriate operational mode and control strategy for catalyst heating. This could involve calculating heating demand, checking safety conditions, and managing various heating phases.

5.  **Output Generation (V.6.4):**
    *   The output of the `OPM X.2`, along with other intermediate signals (possibly from the ignition-related functions), feeds into the `V.6.4` block.
    *   This `V.6.4` block aggregates and processes these signals to produce the final, specific outputs for external use: the catalyst heating control value/status (`<LV_CH>`), the current operational state of the heating system (`<STATE_CH>`), and a relevant temperature difference for heating control (`<TEMP_CAT_DIF_CH_L>`). The internal outputs within `V.6.4` suggest further processing or validation before the final outputs are released.

In summary, the diagram depicts a state-aware, periodically executed control system that uses a wide range of sensor inputs and internal logic, including ignition status, to precisely coordinate and manage the heating of a catalytic converter, ensuring optimal performance for emissions control.

This image contains Simulink diagrams and explanatory text related to automotive system initialization.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram (Figure 38.3.2, supported by Figure 38.3.3 and accompanying text) is to manage the initialization of various parameters, particularly those related to catalyst heating coordination, under different system conditions. It defines how these parameters are set to "neutral" or default values upon a general system reset or during specific operational transitions, such as an engine run-to-stop event.

## Inputs

The key inputs to the system represented in Figure 38.3.2 are:

*   **`init` (Trigger 1)**: A general initialization trigger signal.
*   **`input` (Trigger 2)**: Another trigger signal, likely associated with the `LV_CH_AST_ENA` condition.
*   **`<fc_RST>`**: A trigger signal indicating a system-wide reset event.
*   **`<fc_ERU2ES>`**: A trigger signal indicating a transition from an "engine run" state to an "engine stop" state.
*   **`<LV_CH_AST_ENA>`**: A boolean condition signal, which plays a role in the initialization logic during the engine run-to-stop transition, particularly for lock bits.

## Outputs

The primary output of the system is a single bus named `ini`. This bus consolidates all the initialized parameters. Based on the signals fed into the `BusMerge` block, the `ini` bus implicitly contains the following initialized variables:

*   **`STATE_CH`**
*   **`LV_CH`**
*   **`TEMP_CAT_DIF_CH_L`**
*   **`LV_CH_LOCK`**
*   **`LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK`**
*   **`NR_CTR_L_LOAD_CH_CYC`**

## Logic Flow

The logical flow defines how the system initializes parameters based on different trigger conditions:

1.  **Trigger Reception**: The system monitors two primary trigger conditions: `<fc_RST>` (system reset) and `<fc_ERU2ES>` (engine run-to-stop transition).

2.

**Trigger Reception**: The system monitors two primary trigger conditions: `<fc_RST>` (system reset) and `<fc_ERU2ES>` (engine run-to-stop transition).

2.  **Reset Initialization Path (triggered by `<fc_RST>`)**:
    *   When the `<fc_RST>` signal is active, the `fc_RST()` subsystem (labeled X.1.1 in Figure 38.3.2) is activated.
    *   As detailed in Figure 38.3.3 ("Initialization at reset"), this subsystem sets all its output variables to a neutral value, represented by '0' (from block V.6.4).
    *   The variables initialized in this path are `STATE_CH`, `LV_CH`, `TEMP_CAT_DIF_CH_L`, `LV_CH_LOCK`, `LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK`, and `NR_CTR_L_LOAD_CH_CYC`.
    *   These initialized values are then forwarded to the `BusMerge` block.

3.  **Engine Run to Stop Initialization Path (triggered by `<fc_ERU2ES>`)**:
    *   When the `<fc_ERU2ES>` signal is active, the `fc_ERU2ES()` subsystem (labeled X.1.2 in Figure 38.3.2) is activated.
    *   This subsystem takes `<LV_CH_AST_ENA>` as an input, which influences its internal logic.
    *   According to the text "38.3.1.2 Initialization at transition engine run to engine stop," this path specifically targets "lock bits" (`LV_CH_LOCK` and `LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK`). These lock bits are reset to neutral values either when `LV_CH_AST_ENA` is inactive (if enabled by C_CONF_CH_LOCK bit 3) or during every transition (if enabled by C_CONF_CH_LOCK bit 2).
    *   The initialized `LV_CH_LOCK` and `LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK` values from this path are also forwarded to the `BusMerge` block.

4.  **Bus Merging**: The `BusMerge` block combines all the signals received from both the `fc_RST()` and `fc_ERU2ES()` subsystems into a single output bus named `ini`. This implies that if both paths generate a value for the same variable, the `BusMerge` (or the underlying logic of the paths) determines the precedence or combination rule. Given the distinct nature of the triggers, it's likely that they represent different initialization scenarios that contribute to the final state of the `ini` bus.

5.  **Final Output**: The consolidated `ini` bus, containing the fully initialized set of parameters, is then output from this module.

This image contains two Simulink diagrams, Figure 38.3.4 and Figure 38.3.5, which are parts of an "EXTC Catalyst heating coordination" system.

## Function
The primary function of these interconnected Simulink diagrams is to manage and coordinate the operational states and conditions for automotive catalyst heating. This involves calculating critical lock conditions based on various engine parameters and configuration settings (Figure 38.3.4), and then processing these and other extensive sensor inputs, system statuses, and feedback loops to determine the overall catalyst heating state and control various related flags (Figure 38.3.5).

## Inputs
**Inputs from Figure 38.3.4 (Lock Condition Calculation):**
*   **`LV_CH_AST_ENA`**: Boolean flag indicating if Catalyst After Start heating is enabled.
*   **`num_dec`**: A numeric value or bus from which specific bits are extracted, likely representing system status or configuration registers.
*   **`C_CONF_CH_LOCK`**: A numeric value or bus from which specific bits are extracted, likely representing configuration settings for catalyst heating locks.

**Inputs from Figure 38.3.5 (State Machine and Coordination):**
*   **`NR_CTR_L_LOAD_CH_CYC`**: Counter for low load catalyst heating cycles.
*   **`STATE_CH`**: Current catalyst heating state (feedback loop).
*   **`LV_CH_LOCK`**: Catalyst Heating Lock status (derived from Figure 38.3.4 or feedback).
*   **`LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK`**: Catalyst Heating Low Load Condition Lock status (derived from Figure 38.3.4 or feedback).
*   **`LV_CH_AST_ENA`**: Catalyst After Start Enable status.
*   **`LV_LAMB_OHP`**: Lambda Overheat Protection status.
*   **`LV_TQI_OHP`**: Torque Overheat Protection status.
*   **`LV_ES`**: Engine Speed related status.

*   **`LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK`**: Catalyst Heating Low Load Condition Lock status (derived from Figure 38.3.4 or feedback).
*   **`LV_CH_AST_ENA`**: Catalyst After Start Enable status.
*   **`LV_LAMB_OHP`**: Lambda Overheat Protection status.
*   **`LV_TQI_OHP`**: Torque Overheat Protection status.
*   **`LV_ES`**: Engine Speed related status.
*   **`TEMP_CAT_DYN_MDL_OHP`**: Temperature from catalyst dynamic model indicating overheat protection.
*   **`LV_CH_L_ENA`**: Low Load Catalyst Heating Enable status.
*   **`T_AST_DC`**: After Start Dwell Time.
*   **`LV_IGK`**: Ignition related status.
*   **`ACTION_FARM_SetAuxiliaryStatus_T3`**: Action signal from a Function Alarm Management system for Auxiliary Status T3.
*   **`FAC_SUF_MASS_HEAT_CH`**: Flag indicating sufficient mass for catalyst heating.
*   **`TCO_ST_DC`**: Engine Coolant Temperature status or dwell time.

## Outputs
**Outputs from Figure 38.3.4 (Lock Condition Calculation):**
*   **`LV_CH_LOCK`**: Final Catalyst Heating Lock status (Boolean).
*   **`LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK`**: Final Catalyst Heating Low Load Condition Lock status (Boolean).

**Outputs from Figure 38.3.5 (State Machine and Coordination):**
*   **`STATE_CH`**: The calculated or updated catalyst heating state.
*   **`LV_CH`**: Main catalyst heating status.
*   **`LV_CH_LOCK`**: The calculated or updated catalyst heating lock status.
*   **`LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK`**: The calculated or updated low load condition lock status.
*   **`TEMP_CAT_DIF_CH_L`**: Calculated temperature difference for catalyst heating under low load.
*   **`LV_CH_L_CDN`**: Catalyst heating low load condition status.
*   (Additionally, many of the input signals to `OPM_10MS` appear to be passed through as outputs within the `opm` bus, suggesting they are either modified internally or simply made available as part of a consolidated output data structure.)

## Logic Flow

The system's logic flow proceeds in two main stages, represented by the two diagrams:

**1. Calculation of Catalyst Heating Lock Conditions (Figure 38.3.4):**
This diagram determines two critical lock conditions, `LV_CH_LOCK` and `LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK`.
*   **Step 1: Invert After-Start Enable:** The `LV_CH_AST_ENA` signal is inverted using a `NOT` block.
*   **Step 2: Extract Configuration Bit 1:** A specific bit (bit_sel = 3, from Index Base 0) is extracted from the `num_dec` input.
*   **Step 3: Combine After-Start and Config:** The inverted `LV_CH_AST_ENA` and the extracted bit from `num_dec` are logically combined using an `AND` block (V.6.6). This result contributes to a lock if after-start heating is disabled OR if the specific configuration bit is set.
*   **Step 4: Extract Configuration Bit 2:** Another specific bit (bit_sel = 2, from Index Base 0) is extracted from the `C_CONF_CH_LOCK` input. This likely represents another configurable lock bit.
*   **Step 5: Determine Initial Lock Condition:** The output of the `AND` block (from Step 3) and the extracted bit from `C_CONF_CH_LOCK` (from Step 4) are combined using an `OR` block (V.6.3). The result of this `OR` operation becomes the condition for the subsequent `If` block.
*   **Step 6: Conditional Processing (`If` Block V.6.0):** The `If` block executes paths based on the `OR` condition from Step 5.
    *   One output path from this `If` block generates the value for `LV_CH_LOCK` (which is fed into a `Switch` block).
    *   Another output path from this `If` block directly provides the `LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK` signal as a final output of this diagram.
*   **Step 7: Final `LV_CH_LOCK` Selection (`Switch` Block V.6.1):** A `Switch` block selects the final `LV_CH_LOCK` value.
    *   It uses the `OR` condition from Step 5 (passed from the `If` block) as its control input.

*   Another output path from this `If` block directly provides the `LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK` signal as a final output of this diagram.
*   **Step 7: Final `LV_CH_LOCK` Selection (`Switch` Block V.6.1):** A `Switch` block selects the final `LV_CH_LOCK` value.
    *   It uses the `OR` condition from Step 5 (passed from the `If` block) as its control input.
    *   If the condition is true, it passes the `LV_CH_LOCK` value calculated within the `If` block (from Step 6).
    *   If the condition is false, it passes a constant `0`.
*   **Step 8: Output `LV_CH_LOCK`:** The output of the `Switch` block is the final `LV_CH_LOCK` signal of this diagram.

**2. Catalyst Heating State Machine and Coordination (Figure 38.3.5):**
This diagram encapsulates the main catalyst heating state management logic within a subsystem called `OPM_10MS`.
*   **Step 1: Input Aggregation:** Numerous input signals, including the `LV_CH_LOCK` and `LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK` generated in Figure 38.3.4, along with current system state (`STATE_CH` feedback), and a wide range of other engine and catalyst-related parameters, are fed into the `OPM_10MS` block (Operating Point Management, likely executing every 10 milliseconds).
*   **Step 2: Internal State Calculation (`OPM_10MS` Subsystem):** This subsystem contains the complex logic for catalyst heating coordination. As per the accompanying text, it:
    *   First checks conditions for "after start catalyst heating" (CH_AST) via an internal function `fc_CLC_CH_AST_CDN`.
    *   If those conditions are not met, it then checks conditions for "low load heating" (CH_L_LOAD) via an internal function `fc_CLC_CH_L_CDN`.
    *   Based on all its inputs and internal logic, it computes the current catalyst heating state and other related flags and values.
*   **Step 3: Output Generation and Bus Creation:** The `OPM_10MS` block generates several calculated outputs, including `STATE_CH_out`, `LV_CH_out`, `LV_CH_LOCK_out`, `LV_CH_L_CDN_LOCK_out`, `TEMP_CAT_DIF_CH_L`, and `LV_CH_L_CDN`. These, along with several pass-through input signals, are then collected and output as a single bus labeled `opm`.

This image presents a Simulink diagram, specifically Figure 38.3.9, which is part of a larger document titled "EXTC: Catalyst heating coordination."

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to coordinate and manage the conditions for catalyst heating, specifically determining when Low Voltage Catalyst Heating (LV_CH) should be active, whether a Nominal Control Load Catalyst Heating Cycle is indicated, and a catalyst temperature difference for heating. It uses various temperature thresholds, duty cycle limits, and dynamic model outputs to achieve this coordination, employing a state-holding mechanism (SR flip-flop) for the main heating condition.

## Inputs

*   **`C_TEMP_CAT_THD_CH_L_ON`**: Catalyst temperature threshold for turning heating ON (constant/parameter).
*   **`TEMP_CAT_DYN_MDL_OHP`**: Dynamic model over-heat protection temperature (signal).
*   **`LV_CH_ENA`**: Low Voltage Catalyst Heating Enable (boolean signal).
*   **`<TCO_ST_DC>`**: Temperature catalytic converter start-up duty cycle (signal).
*   **`C_TCO_ST_DC_MIN_CH_L_LOAD`**: Minimum duty cycle for catalyst heating during start-up load (constant/parameter).

## Function

The primary function of this system is to calculate and manage a **Mass Air Flow (MAF) integration value (`MAF_INT_CH`)**. This value represents the total mass of air that has passed through the engine over time, subjected to specific scaling, offsets, and saturation limits. The calculation of `MAF_INT_CH` is conditionally executed based on engine operational states, and the resulting value is used by higher-level control logic to coordinate or disable catalyst heating. The context suggests that a high accumulated `MAF_INT_CH` may indicate sufficient engine operation, allowing for the deactivation of supplemental catalyst heating.

## Function
The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to determine whether catalyst heating should be deactivated (`LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF`) based on the occurrence of specific component failures (`NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_A`, `NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_B`) and a system-wide action permission (`ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3`) from the "FARM interface" (likely a Fault Accumulation and Reporting Mechanism). Essentially, it sets an error flag that leads to the deactivation of catalyst heating if certain failure conditions are met and permitted.

## Inputs
*   **`<ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3>`**: A boolean signal indicating whether the FARM interface grants permission for the action (deactivation of catalyst heating). This acts as an enabling condition for the failure-based deactivation.

Essentially, it sets an error flag that leads to the deactivation of catalyst heating if certain failure conditions are met and permitted.

## Inputs
*   **`<ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3>`**: A boolean signal indicating whether the FARM interface grants permission for the action (deactivation of catalyst heating). This acts as an enabling condition for the failure-based deactivation.
*   **`NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_A`**: A boolean flag or identifier representing the status of a specific component failure (Failure A) that can lead to catalyst heating deactivation.
*   **`NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_B`**: A boolean flag or identifier representing the status of another specific component failure (Failure B) that can lead to catalyst heating deactivation.

## Outputs
*   **`<LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF>`**: A boolean flag that, when `TRUE`, indicates that catalyst heating should be deactivated due to an error condition.

## Logic Flow

The logic flow shown in Figure 38.411 determines the state of `<LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF>` through a series of logical operations, integrating failure statuses with an action permission.

1.  **Failure Condition Evaluation (A):**
    *   The `NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_A` input, representing Failure A, is first processed by a `PRM_FID` block (likely to retrieve or evaluate parameters associated with this specific fault identifier).
    *   The output from `PRM_FID` and the `<ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3>` signal are fed into an "ActionImport" block. Based on the overall logic required by the accompanying text ("As soon as one of these is set, this leads to setting of LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF"), this "ActionImport" block is interpreted to output `FALSE` if Failure A is active *and* `ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3` is `TRUE` (i.e., action is permitted), and `TRUE` otherwise. Let's call this output `Condition_A_Deactivation_Prevented`.

2.  **Failure Condition Evaluation (B):**
    *   Similarly, the `NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_B` input (Failure B) is processed by a second `PRM_FID` block.
    *   Its output and the same `<ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3>` signal are fed into an identical "ActionImport" block. This block also outputs `FALSE` if Failure B is active *and* `ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3` is `TRUE`, and `TRUE` otherwise. Let's call this output `Condition_B_Deactivation_Prevented`.

3.  **Combine Deactivation Prevention Conditions (AND Gate - V.6.10):**
    *   The outputs `Condition_A_Deactivation_Prevented` and `Condition_B_Deactivation_Prevented` are fed into an `AND` gate.
    *   The `AND` gate's output will be `TRUE` only if *both* `Condition_A_Deactivation_Prevented` is `TRUE` *and* `Condition_B_Deactivation_Prevented` is `TRUE`. This implies that neither Failure A nor Failure B is active and permitted to cause deactivation.
    *   Conversely, the `AND` gate's output will be `FALSE` if *at least one* of the failures (A or B) is active *and* `ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3` is `TRUE`, thereby causing the "deactivation prevented" condition to be `FALSE`.

4.  **Determine Catalyst Heating Deactivation (NOT Gate - V.6.8):**
    *   The output of the `AND` gate is then inverted by a `NOT` gate.
    *   If the `AND` gate output is `TRUE` (meaning deactivation is prevented for both failures), the `NOT` gate outputs `FALSE` for `<LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF>`.
    *   If the `AND` gate output is `FALSE` (meaning at least one failure is active and permitted, hence deactivation is *not* prevented), the `NOT` gate outputs `TRUE` for `<LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF>`.

5.  **Final Output:**
    *   The output of the `NOT` gate directly sets the `<LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF>` flag.
    *   Therefore, `<LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF>` becomes `TRUE` if (`NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_A` is `TRUE` OR `NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_B` is `TRUE`) AND `ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3` is `TRUE`.

5.  **Final Output:**
    *   The output of the `NOT` gate directly sets the `<LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF>` flag.
    *   Therefore, `<LV_ERR_CH_SET_OFF>` becomes `TRUE` if (`NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_A` is `TRUE` OR `NC_FID_FCT_CH_SET_OFF_B` is `TRUE`) AND `ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3` is `TRUE`.
    *   This logic ensures that catalyst heating is set off if either failure condition A or B occurs, provided that the FARM interface grants permission for this deactivation.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and manage parameters related to catalyst heating in an automotive system. Specifically, it computes a correction value for catalyst heating (`<T_AST_COR_CH>`) and derives several boolean flags that enable or disable different aspects of catalyst heating based on engine operating conditions (engine speed, requested torque), diagnostic values, and system configuration settings.

## Inputs

*   **`LV_T_AST_COR_CH_ENA`** (Boolean): Local Variable - Enable signal for the T_AST Catalyst Heating Correction.
*   **`EFF_CAT_DIAG_MV`** (Numerical): Effective Catalyst Diagnostic Measured Value.
*   **`C_CONF_CDN_CAT_HEAT`** (Byte/Integer): Configuration Constant - A byte containing multiple bit flags that define various conditions and allowances for catalyst heating.
*   **`TQI_REQ_TRA`** (Numerical): Requested Torque from the Driver.
*   **`N`** (Numerical): Engine Speed.
*   **`LV_ST_END`** (Boolean): Local Variable - Indicates if the engine start sequence has finished (True if engine is running or start is complete, False during engine start).

## Outputs

*   **`<T_AST_COR_CH>`** (Numerical): The calculated corrected value for catalyst heating (e.g., a temperature correction).
*   **`<LV_CH_L_ENA>`** (Boolean): Local Variable - Enable flag for Low Load Catalyst Heating.
*   **`<LV_CH_AST_ENA>`** (Boolean): Local Variable - Enable flag for After-Start Catalyst Heating.
*   **`<LV_TQI_CH_AST_ENA>`** (Boolean): Local Variable - Enable flag for Torque-Requested Catalyst Heating during the After-Start phase.

## Logic Flow

The diagram's logic can be broken down into four main paths, each contributing to an output:

1.  **Calculation of `<T_AST_COR_CH>` (Catalyst Heating Correction):**
    *   The `LV_T_AST_COR_CH_ENA` signal is first inverted by a `NOT` gate. The inverted signal, along with the original, feeds into a `cond_if` block, suggesting a conditional activation or reset mechanism.
    *   The `EFF_CAT_DIAG_MV` and the original `LV_T_AST_COR_CH_ENA` are processed by a function block `fc()`.
    *   The output of `fc()` and an internal signal `ip_t_ast_cor_ch` are then processed by another function block `CLC_T_AST_COR_CH`.
    *   The result from `CLC_T_AST_COR_CH` is continuously summed with its previous output in an accumulator-like block (indicated by `1 + z^-1` with an initial value of 0). This effectively integrates or accumulates the value over time.
    *   The final accumulated value, `LV_T_AST_COR_CH_ENA_tmp`, is the primary numerical output `<T_AST_COR_CH>`.

2.  **Calculation of `<LV_CH_L_ENA>` (Low Load Catalyst Heating Enable):**
    *   The `C_CONF_CDN_CAT_HEAT` configuration byte is analyzed, and bit 2 (`bit_sel = 2`) is extracted. According to the accompanying text, bit 2 being '1' means "low load catalyst heating is active."
    *   The extracted bit's value is then inverted by a `NOT` gate.
    *   The result of this `NOT` operation directly becomes the `<LV_CH_L_ENA>` output.

3.  **Calculation of `<LV_CH_AST_ENA>` (After-Start Catalyst Heating Enable):**
    *   Bit 0 (`bit_sel = 0`) and Bit 1 (`bit_sel = 1`) are extracted from the `C_CONF_CDN_CAT_HEAT` configuration byte.
        *   Bit 0: "catalyst heating is generally allowed."
        *   Bit 1: "catalyst heating is manually allowed."

3.  **Calculation of `<LV_CH_AST_ENA>` (After-Start Catalyst Heating Enable):**
    *   Bit 0 (`bit_sel = 0`) and Bit 1 (`bit_sel = 1`) are extracted from the `C_CONF_CDN_CAT_HEAT` configuration byte.
        *   Bit 0: "catalyst heating is generally allowed."
        *   Bit 1: "catalyst heating is manually allowed."
    *   Bit 0 and Bit 1 are combined using an `AND` gate.
    *   The output of this `AND` gate is then combined with Bit 1 (extracted again) using an `OR` gate. Logically, the expression `( (Bit0 AND Bit1) OR Bit1 )` simplifies to `Bit1`.
    *   The result of this `OR` operation directly becomes the `<LV_CH_AST_ENA>` output, meaning this flag is enabled if "catalyst heating is manually allowed."

4.  **Calculation of `<LV_TQI_CH_AST_ENA>` (Torque-Requested Catalyst Heating After-Start Enable):**
    *   The engine speed `N` is used as an input to a 1D lookup table `IP_TQI_REQ_TRA_THD_CH` to determine a dynamic torque threshold (`IP_val`).
    *   The `TQI_REQ_TRA` (Requested Torque) is compared to this `IP_val` using a `LESS THAN` operator (`<`).
    *   Simultaneously, the `LV_ST_END` signal (engine start finished) is inverted by a `NOT` gate, making it true during the engine start phase.
    *   The result of the torque comparison `(TQI_REQ_TRA < Threshold)` and the inverted `LV_ST_END` are combined using an `AND` gate. This `AND` gate output drives the `SET` input of an SR Flip-Flop (FF).
    *   The `RST` (Reset) input of the SR Flip-Flop is directly driven by `LV_ST_END`.
    *   The `Q` output of the Flip-Flop, after passing through a buffer/signal block, becomes `<LV_TQI_CH_AST_ENA>`. This logic sets the flag to true if the requested torque is below the speed-dependent threshold *and* the engine start phase is active. The flag is then reset to false once the engine start phase completes (`LV_ST_END` becomes true).

    *   Two critical external outputs, `<NR_IV_PLS_REQ_CH>` and `<STATE_CH_MOD>`, are generated from these computations and sent to other engine control modules. These outputs directly influence how the engine operates to heat the catalyst.
    *   Finally, the `OPM X.2` block also generates a `<feedback>` signal that loops back to the `INI X.1` block. This feedback mechanism allows the system to maintain context and ensure that the next initialization or operational cycle starts from a state consistent with the previous cycle's results.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to determine the "Actual Catalyst Heating Mode State" (`<STATE_CH_MOD>`). This state is calculated based on the values of two input variables, `IDX_CMB_MOD_CH` and `NC_IDX_SUM_CH_SNG`, in relation to a common system parameter `V.6.2`. ## Inputs

1.  **`<IDX_CMB_MOD_CH>`**: An input signal representing a combined mode index for catalyst heating. It's a key factor in determining an intermediate catalyst heating mode (either "Home Mode" or "MPLH Mode").
2.  **`<NC_IDX_SUM_CH_SNG>`**: An input signal representing a normalized count index sum for catalyst heating (single). This input acts as a gating condition, determining whether the calculated intermediate mode is active or if the system should revert to a default/off state.
3.  **`V.6.2`**: A system parameter or constant value used as a reference for comparison in both `==` blocks. Its exact meaning is context-dependent but acts as a threshold or specific mode identifier.
4.  **`CH_MOD_HOM` (value 1)**: A constant value representing one of the possible intermediate catalyst heating modes, typically indicating a "Home Mode" or default active mode.
5.  **`CH_MOD_MPLH` (value 2)**: A constant value representing another possible intermediate catalyst heating mode, likely indicating a "Multi-Pulse Light-off Heating Mode".
